title: Congress Raises Standards for Assessing New Airliner Designs
summary: Year-end spending bill includes bipartisan provisions toughening FAA oversight of future aircraft models. Congress approved significantly tighter rules for accepting jetliner designs as part of a year-end federal omnibus spending bill, the final step to locking in safety overhauls sparked by two fatal Boeing Co. 737 MAX jet crashes.

title: SolarWinds Hack Hit Office Home to Top Treasury Department Officials
summary: Suspected Russian hack compromised dozens of Treasury Department email accounts, senator says. WASHINGTON-Suspected Russian hackers compromised dozens of Treasury department email accounts and breached the office that houses its top officials, as part of a broad campaign targeting several critical federal government agencies, a senior senator said Monday.

title: China's Liquor Giants Intoxicate Investors
summary: Baijiu makers Kweichow Moutai and Wuliangye Yibin are riding a hot streak thanks to China's growing thirst for pricier drinks. A dizzying rally this year has put China's top distillers firmly in the ranks of the world's most valuable consumer-goods companies.

title: Sinovac's Covid-19 Vaccine Shown Effective in Brazil Trials
summary: Brazil is first country to complete Phase 3 trials of Chinese company's vaccine; official results due out Wednesday. SÃO PAULO-Sinovac Biotech Ltd.'s Covid-19 vaccine, which scientists hope can help combat the pandemic in the developing world, has passed the 50% threshold for efficacy in late-stage trials in Brazil, meaning regulators can give it the green light for use, people involved in its development said.

title: Long-Haul Covid Patients Put Hope in Experimental Drugs
summary: People suffering from debilitating symptoms for months after getting sick with Covid are searching for relief. Patrick Varnes has suffered from shortness of breath, fatigue and headaches for about six months since being diagnosed with Covid at the end of June. The 41-year-old financial director in Atlanta says he has tried nearly 30 different supplements, acupuncture and a steroid.

title: The Martini Lunch Tax Code
summary: Trump and the GOP revive the loophole for business meals. It's bad policy and bad politics.. Congress's latest Covid relief and omnibus spending bills are a mash-up of special favors for teachers unions, the booze industry, wind power, race horses, and so much more. There's even a bailout for Broadway; take a bow, Chuck Schumer. But for a sign of the political times, and how far Congress has strayed from basic economic logic, you can't beat the return of the full business meal deduction.

title: The Year in Space Travel
summary: SpaceX keeps making remarkable rocket launches look routine.. We don't have to remind readers of the ways that 2020 has been dispiriting, but there's been some good news. The Covid vaccine rollout is a tribute to American ingenuity, and then there's the remarkable success of the SpaceX rocket launches.

title: Trump's Parting Shot: A Bigger Navy?
summary: The U.S. needs more ships to counter China and project power.. The Trump Administration is spending some of its last days in office provoking a debate about building a larger and more lethal U.S.Navy to check China in the Pacific. This political document arrives late, but give the Trump Team credit for issuing this challenge to President-elect Joe Biden.

title: New York City's Worst Slumlord
summary: Yet another scandal at the nation's largest housing authority.. Mayor Bill de Blasio and the New York City Housing Authority (Nycha) are the worst landlords in the Big Apple, according to a watch list released last week by the city's public advocate. A new report by the New York City Department of Investigation offers some supporting evidence.

title: MGM Holdings, Studio Behind 'James Bond,' Explores a Sale
summary: Movie studio has tapped bankers to find a buyer, as media companies look to stock up on content. MGM Holdings Inc., the movie studio behind the "James Bond" franchise, is exploring a sale, according to people familiar with the matter, betting that its library of content will prove attractive to companies pursuing growth in streaming video.

title: Brewers, Restaurants, Federal Workers Set for Tax Wins in Congressional Deal
summary: Congress will prevent alcohol taxes from rising Jan. 1, while offering a business-meals deduction President Trump sought. WASHINGTON-The beer industry, struggling restaurants and federal workers forced into President Trump's payroll-tax deferral all stand to gain from the year-end congressional agreement reached Sunday.

title: Iran Isn't Afraid of B-52s and Aircraft Carriers
summary: The U.S. should redeploy its big guns to counter the conventional threat from Russia and China.. Troubling signs suggest Iran is stepping up its aggression. U.S. Central Command has sounded a familiar refrain: More forces, please. Defense Department leadership has approved. On Dec. 10, the Pentagon announced that B-52 bombers had conducted another "short-notice, nonstop" flight from the U.S. to the Middle East and back. The department also extended a carrier strike group in the Persian Gulf and deployed a fighter squadron to the region from Europe. It took the rare step Sunday of announcing the transit of a guided-missile submarine through the Strait of Hormuz. All supposedly to deter Iran.

title: USGS Gets Politics Out of Climate Forecasts
summary: My agency makes a significant advance in the government's approach to science.. The world's climate is changing, as it always has. The challenge is to understand how and why, which is why the U.S. Geological Survey has adopted the most comprehensive climate analysis requirements ever implemented by the federal government.

title: Beijing's Collision With Christians
summary: As the faith spreads, the Communist Party fears a threat to its political control.. With the European Parliament threatening to block an investment deal with China over persecution of Muslims in Xinjiang, the shock waves released by Beijing's Hong Kong crackdown still reverberating, and the debate over the next U.S. administration's China policy heating up, this would seem like a bad time for Beijing to kick off another major international dustup over human rights.

title: Notable & Quotable: The Unwoke Abe Lincoln
summary: 'Lincoln, like the presidents before him and most after, did not show through policy or rhetoric that Black lives ever mattered to them.'. From "Abraham Lincoln was once a hero. In some S.F. education circles, he's now a bad guy," San Francisco Chronicle, Dec. 11:

title: Will Georgia Elect Mitch McConnell?
summary: Both parties are saying the stakes are national in the two Jan. 5 Senate runoffs.. Tip O'Neill famously advised that "all politics is local." Not on Jan. 5 and not in Georgia.

title: 'The Golden Thread' Review: Who Killed Dag Hammarskjöld?
summary: After his plane crashed, conflicting clues and witnesses emerged and records went missing. It's one of the unsolved mysteries of our times.. As the story has been told and retold, the man "was lying slightly away from the carnage. Though he was clearly dead, he looked untouched save for specks of blood on his face. His blue eyes, now lifeless, were still open. He was surrounded by playing cards. One of them, the ace of spades, was on his body."

title: U.K. Assets Fall Over Deadlocked Brexit Talks, New Lockdowns
summary: British pound fell as much as 2.3% against the dollar in trading before recovering some of its losses. The British pound weakened against the dollar and U.K. stocks fell as the continuing failure to arrive at a post-Brexit trade agreement and new measures in the U.K. to curtail the spread of Covid-19 weighed on British assets.

title: Ex-NBA Player's Group Named Winning Bidder for Bankrupt Ebony Media
summary: The $14 million offer from Ulysses "Junior" Bridgeman was sole serious bid for publisher of Black magazines. Ebony Media Operations LLC plans to sell its business to an investment group led by former NBA player Ulysses "Junior" Bridgeman for about $14 million, the only serious offer received by the bankrupt publisher of Black magazines.

title: Biden Gets Vaccine, but Does He Understand It?
summary: President-elect still forecasting crisis after his inauguration.. In the days leading up to the November elections Joe Biden told some whoppers on the subject of health care. Perhaps that's to be expected in the heat of a political campaign. But his post-election comments are harder to figure. Mr. Biden's Monday Covid-19 vaccination in Delaware proves he now understands that his consistent skepticism about the Trump administration's Operation Warp Speed was misguided. Yet Mr. Biden continues to promote the same policy agenda based on his original false premise.

title: Echo of Coronavirus Didn't Keep Beer Drinkers From Corona
summary: Early headlines suggested that drinkers would hold an unfortunate overlap in names against the brand. A series of headlines early in the coronavirus pandemic suggested that its many impacts could include damage to a beer brand with a suddenly awkward name.

title: What Was Bill Barr's Job and Did He Do It?
summary: Ever since he took the job, the attorney general has been the target of harsh attacks from both the left and the right.. So much was asked of Attorney General Bill Barr ("Thank You, Bill Barr," Review & Outlook, Dec. 15). The American people needed him to identify the corruption in Washington, hold officials accountable for the Russia hoax and alert voters that Joe Biden's son was under investigation. Mr. Barr did none of this. His tenure must be judged a failure.

title: Dear Andy: Going to Space Helps Us on Earth
summary: Walk into any hospital-patient's room in America and see the life-saving benefit of our space program.. Andy Kessler is right to ask "Dear NASA: What's in It for Me?" (Inside View, Dec. 14), but he seems to miss how this question has been answered by the history of exploration. Columbus thought he had found a new route to Asia. Not quite. But would anyone deny that wealth and opportunities followed his discovery?

title: Cut Ludwig van Beethoven's Father Some Slack, Will Ya?
summary: Fatherhood is the most thankless of jobs. If you are too hard, you are a tyrant. If you are too soft, you aren't setting a good example.. After Timothy Mullaly's wonderful letter about his father's sacrifice ("The Human Cost of Massive Plant Closures," Dec. 9), I was disappointed to see Andrew Lennon take a shot at Beethoven's father, Johann ("Beethoven's Fifth, Ninth and 250th," op-ed, Dec. 17). Fatherhood is the most thankless of jobs. If you are too hard, you are a tyrant. If you are too soft, you aren't setting a good example. Let us not forget Robert Hayden's lines from "Those Winter Sundays," a reflection on the work his father had silently done for him:

title: Trump and Republicans Are to Blame for Damage to the Political System
summary: Historians will write about the attempt to overturn the election result, not an 'outburst' from an appeals court judge.. In "Judge Sullivan's Final 'Verdict'" (Potomac Watch, Dec. 11), Kimberley A. Strassel calls the judge's dismissal of charges against Michael Flynn "a reminder that for all the caterwauling these past four years about the breaking of 'norms' and 'standards,' the unhinged critics of Mr. Trump have done the most damage to the system."

title: 'Hearts and Minds' Must Be Won in Concert, Never Apart
summary: Even the decision to be logical is based on emotions.. Bobby Jindal and Alex Castellanos perpetuate the myth that there is a divide between emotional decisions and logical ones ("There's More to Politics than Policy," op-ed, Dec. 11). While there are separate parts of the brain associated with each mental activity, even the decision to be logical is based on emotions. We want to convince ourselves we are making the "right" decision; we believe that logic will convince others because it is superior to emotions. Further evidence comes from the well-known examples of anger causing a person to make low-payoff, risky decisions. There is even physical evidence to support the notion that emotions are the basis of logical decisions. Research shows that people with damage to the part of the brain associated with emotions have difficulty making decisions.

title: U.K. Braces for Possible Shortages of Some Foods as France Closes Border to Trade Over New Covid Strain
summary: Travel ban on passengers and freight across English Channel threatens trade of up to 10,000 trucks a day. FOLKESTONE, England-A line of trucks stretched for miles back from the entrance to the Channel tunnel here Monday, as the U.K. braced for potential food shortages and manufacturers worried over more disruptions if France continued a ban on freight and passenger traffic from Britain to stop the spread of a new strain of the coronavirus.

title: New York Sees Boost in Latest Covid-19 Aid Package
summary: Metropolitan Transportation Authority, cultural institutions expected to get funding in $900 billion deal. New York's cultural institutions, transit riders and small businesses will see some relief from the $900 billion federal coronavirus aid package that is expected to pass Congress after months of wrangling between Republicans and Democrats.

title: New Covid-19 Strain Can't Overturn Bullish Narrative Yet
summary: Selloff in risky assets is predictable reaction to coronavirus strain, but for now the news doesn't justify a more negative outlook. Europe's mutated coronavirus doesn't yet pose an existential threat to the market narrative that has become a reasonable consensus since late March and particularly since the news of the efficacy of vaccines in November.

title: Diamondback Buys Shale Driller QEP Resources
summary: All-stock deal is valued at $2.2 billion including debt. Diamondback Energy Inc. has agreed to buy West Texas rival QEP Resources Inc. in an all-stock deal, extending a run of low-premium takeovers in the shale patch.

title: Joe Biden Gets Covid-19 Vaccine
summary: President-elect got the first of two shots during a televised appearance from Delaware hospital. President-elect Joe Biden received the Covid-19 vaccine Monday in a televised appearance from a Delaware hospital in which he encouraged the public to get vaccinated. "There's nothing to worry about," he said.

title: Stocks Mostly Finish Lower Amid Fresh Covid-19 Travel Restrictions
summary: Curbs designed to stop a fast-spreading coronavirus variant from the U.K. hit shares in U.S., Europe. The S&P 500 fell Monday as a rapidly spreading strain of coronavirus emerging from England prompted fresh travel restrictions, dealing a setback for the global economic recovery.

title: Bomb-Maker Admitted to Building Device Used in Lockerbie Explosion, U.S. Prosecutors Say
summary: Officials seek to bring suspect who allegedly made bombs for Moammar Gadhafi to U.S. to face trial. WASHINGTON-An alleged bomb-maker for the late Libyan dictator Moammar Gadhafi has admitted to assembling the device that blew up a commercial jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, shedding what Justice Department officials said Monday was new light on a long-stalled inquiry into a terrorist attack that killed 270 people.

title: Temperature-Tracking Tools Take Center Stage in Covid-19 Vaccine Rollout
summary: Devices ranging from sophisticated sensors to heat-sensitive labels help ensure the fragile doses are maintained at the right levels in high-stakes supply chains. When several trays of the fragile Covid-19 vaccine shipped out last week were found to have fallen outside the specified temperature range, the incident put a spotlight on the increasingly sophisticated tracking devices that buttress the immunization effort.

title: 'Wonder Woman 1984': Wishfulness Run Riot
summary: Gal Gadot returns as the Amazon hero in a chaotic follow-up to the 2017 hit.. As "Wonder Woman 1984" began streaming in preview on my living-room screen, I felt something of the pre-Covid thrill of sitting in a theater and being drawn into the 2017 "Wonder Woman," a terrific action spectacular starring Gal Gadot as the Amazon warrior princess Diana. That one included a flashback to Themyscira, the Amazons' island home, where Diana as a child was being trained in martial arts. The sequel, with Ms. Gadot once again in the title role, starts with another flashback to Themyscira, but Diana, nearly into adolescence and played as before by Lilly Aspell, is competing against formidable women in the Amazon Games, a succession of challenges that make the Olympics look like hopscotch. This opening sequence is as elegant and exciting as anyone could have wished for. When it's over, though, the film, opening in theaters and streaming on HBO Max, turns coarse, shrill and chaotic, a kinetic but uncomic concoction that plays like some demented sendup of the Make-A-Wish Foundation

title: New Jersey Lawmakers Approve Corporate Tax-Break Program
summary: Democratic governor says he will sign bill into law while critics say tax credits give up too much potential revenue. New Jersey lawmakers have approved a new economic-development incentive program that authorizes $14 billion in corporate subsidies over seven years.

title: Family Holiday (Tuesday Crossword, December 22)
'Only 1 in Stock!' The Mystery of a Stolen Stradivarius Takes a Twist
summary: Resume Subscription. When violinist David Sarser got a last-minute call on Aug. 16, 1962, to perform at NBC Studios, he went to his Midtown Manhattan music studio to grab his prized Stradivarius violin. It was gone.

title: Oil Prices Tumble on New Covid-19 Travel Restrictions
summary: Countries across Europe and beyond bar travelers from the U.K. to curtail the spread of a highly infectious variant of the coronavirus. Oil prices fell Monday after a new strain of coronavirus discovered in the U.K. sparked fresh travel restrictions across Europe and concerns that there may be more lockdowns globally.

title: U.K. Regulator Fines Charles Schwab Unit $12.1 Million
summary: The Financial Conduct Authority said the company carried out a regulated activity without the proper permission. The U.K.'s Financial Conduct Authority said Monday that it has fined Charles Schwab UK Ltd. £8.96 million ($12.1 million) over failing to protect client assets.

title: Texas Challenges Legality of DACA in Latest Bid to End the Program
summary: Judge to revisit case over Obama-era program, leaving young immigrants who benefit from its protections in legal limbo. Texas and eight other Republican-led states will ask a federal court on Tuesday to rule the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program unlawful, posing a fresh threat to the Obama-era program offering deportation protections to young immigrants that has been the subject of legal battles for the past few years.

title: Chopped Steak With Garlic and Rosemary
summary: Chopped up and formed into patties along with capers, mustard and garlic, beef sirloin gets a good, crispy sear on the outside and remains pink and succulent within. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Lockerbie Charges Punctuate Decadeslong Mission for Barr
summary: Signal terrorism case resurfaces on 32nd anniversary of airline bombing that killed 270 people. WASHINGTON-Attorney General William Barr's announcement Monday of U.S. charges against a man accused of assembling the device that blew up Pan Am Flight 103 in 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland, marks a further step toward a goal he set nearly three decades ago.

title: Barr Won't Appoint Special Counsel to Probe Vote-Fraud Claims or Hunter Biden
summary: Attorney general says he believes the investigation into President-elect Joe Biden's son is 'being handled responsibly and professionally'. WASHINGTON-Attorney General William Barr said he saw no reason to appoint a special counsel to investigate allegations against Hunter Biden or election fraud on Monday, saying he believed the investigation into President-elect Joe Biden's son was "being handled responsibly and professionally."

title: Answers to Questions About the Legal Fight Over the Dreamers
summary: Obama-era program offering protections to young immigrants in the country without authorization has faced rounds of court challenges. A federal court in Texas is set to hear a case challenging the legality of Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, an Obama-era program offering some deportation protections to young immigrants living in the country illegally. It marks the latest twist in a long-running legal battle over the program that has created uncertainty for DACA recipients since 2017. Here are some questions and answers about where the legal battle now stands.

title: A Great Way to Cook Steak at Home, According to a Top Chef
summary: Chopped up and formed into patties along with capers, mustard and garlic, beef sirloin gets a good, crispy sear on the outside and remains pink and succulent within. CHEFS OFTEN INSPIRE other chefs to greatness. That's the story behind Rebecca Wilcomb's third Slow Food Fast recipe.

title: How to Work From Home Effectively
summary: Most Popular News. Remote work has been on the rise across the U.S. for years, but the coronavirus pandemic significantly accelerated the shift to remote work. This is especially the case for industries and roles that don't require employees to work in person. "People have learned that this is more possible in roles that they didn't think it was possible in before," says Sara Sutton, chief executive and founder of FlexJobs, a career website for telecommuting, flexible, freelance and part-time jobs. She says getting workers set up to be able to work remotely at any time is like an insurance policy for employers in case they find themselves in a similar situation in the future. "I don't think there's any organization that is going to realize they should leave this opportunity on the table."

title: Tesla Stock Slides on First Day of Trading in S&P 500
summary: The slump suggests some investors were cashing out following the electric-car maker's addition to the S&P 500. Shares of Tesla Inc. declined in their S&P 500 debut Monday as the massive wave of demand that had propelled the stock ahead of its inclusion subsided.

title: Companies' Racial-Equity Pledges Raise Challenge: Following the Money
summary: Corporations say they are using their financial might to narrow racial wealth and opportunity gap; tracking those efforts can be tough. U.S. companies pledged tens of billions of dollars toward racial-equity efforts in 2020. A challenge for 2021 and beyond: tracking where the dollars go and what changes the pledges will bring.

title: A Pandemic of Misinformation
summary: The media's politicization of Covid has proved deadly and puts Americans' freedoms at risk.. America has been paralyzed by death and fear for nearly a year, and the politicization of the pandemic has made things worse by adding misinformation and vitriol to the mix. With vaccines finally being administered, we should be entering a joyous phase. Instead we endure still more inflammatory rhetoric and media distortion.

title: How the Woke Stole Christmas
summary: Cotton Mather deplored 'masking' but otherwise sounds a lot like 2020's coronavirus commissars.. It will be a puritan sort of Christmas for most of us this year: confined to our homes, maintaining a distance from each other, avoiding public revelry on penalty of a hefty fine. If you do go to church, remember-no singing, by order of the elders. California Gov. Gavin Newsom is not the first flamboyantly coiffed authoritarian governor-protector in history to ban the singing of Christmas carols. But at least Oliver Cromwell never went near a French laundry, as far as we know.

title: From Jackie O to Rihanna, the Ultimate Guide to Classic Style
summary: What constitutes a fashion classic? The term is often used indiscriminately, but this (admittedly subjective) A-Z guide-featuring Chanel suits, Hermès bags, blue jeans and much more-might help.. NOW IS the time to embrace the classics. OK, fine, it's never not that time, but today, favoring such pieces over fleeting trends seems particularly prudent. "Trends are connected with timing and, in a way, time has stood still for the last year," said New York fashion editor and author Tonne Goodman. "There's comfort in knowing you have something that's going to last."

title: Covid Prompts Families to Shun Nursing Homes, a Shift That Appears Long Lasting
summary: Resume Subscription. The pandemic is reshaping the way Americans care for their elderly, prompting family decisions to avoid nursing homes and keep loved ones in their own homes for rehabilitation and other care.

title: Danske Bank Cleared of U.S. Sanctions Liability for Estonia Scandal
summary: The U.S. Treasury Department's sanctions watchdog has closed an investigation into the Danish lender. The U.S. Treasury Department's sanctions watchdog has closed an investigation into a money-laundering scandal at Danske Bank A/S's Estonia branch, the Danish lender said.

title: Anti-Semitic Tweets Targeting Miss France Contestant Spark Investigation
summary: April Benayoum spoke about father's Israeli background during televised pageant. PARIS-French prosecutors have opened an investigation into a barrage of anti-Semitic insults hurled over social media at the runner-up of the Miss France beauty pageant after she mentioned her father's Israeli background during the show.

title: Indian Health Service Improves on Sexual-Abuse Safeguards, Report Finds
summary: Health-care agency still must do more to encourage staff to report suspected abuse, officials say. The U.S. Indian Health Service made sweeping changes to better protect patients from sexual misconduct but administrators at most agency facilities said barriers still exist that could deter staff from reporting abuses, federal inspectors said Monday.

title: Feeling Depressed? Bacteria in Your Gut May Be to Blame
summary: New studies point to the trillions of organisms in the human microbiome as playing an unexpectedly huge role in our well-being.

title: Biden Talks Up Bipartisanship; He Has Three Good Reasons
summary: Democrats and Republicans are sharply divided, but the president-elect has ways to forge consensus. It is a sure sign we have reached the sour end to a sour year that President-elect Joe Biden is being criticized in some quarters for being too optimistic about his chances of working cooperatively with Republicans.

title: Do You Need to Shower Every Day?
summary: Here's what doctors say about the effect of frequent showers on your health and your skin. Working from home has some people slowing down their showering routines to a trickle. How often should you bathe and what do doctors say about showering less?

title: Denmark to Dig Up Millions of Dead Mink After Botched Covid-19 Cull
summary: The mink carcasses will be incinerated over fears they could contaminate water supplies. Denmark will dig up millions of dead mink it culled to stamp out a potentially dangerous mutation of the virus that causes Covid-19, only to find that their rotting carcasses could cause a fresh contamination risk.

title: Mnuchin Says Stimulus Payments to Households Could Come Next Week
summary: Checks would be part of the Covid-19 aid deal that is set to be passed by Congress. Households could begin receiving $600 in direct payments as soon as the beginning of next week under the Covid-19 aid deal set to be passed by Congress, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said.

title: Bachelor Pad? Sure. Just Don't Call This Designer's Work a Man Cave
summary: Lauren Svenstrup breaks down her approach to designing practical yet sophisticated spaces for men. When designing a bachelor pad, one designer likens her hassle-free approach to that of a concierge.

title: Pfizer-BioNTech Vaccine Cleared by EU Agency
summary: European Medicines Agency recommends authorization for the shot, clearing way for formal approval this week. BRUSSELS-The Covid-19 vaccine from Pfizer Inc. and its German partner BioNTech SE was cleared for use by the European Union's drug agency, a major step in efforts to tame the disease in a region that is fighting a deadly winter surge, as the bloc also tries to keep out a new mutation in the coronavirus found in Britain.

title: Should People Who Have Had Covid-19 Wait to Get a Vaccine?
summary: As immunizations roll out, scientists and public-health experts ask if those who have already had the coronavirus should consider deferring shots. As the first Covid-19 vaccine doses roll out across the country, a question has emerged among scientists and public-health experts: Should people who have already had the virus consider deferring vaccination?

title: Covid-19 Means Smaller Crowds at Rockefeller Center's Christmas Tree
summary: The Rockettes aren't kicking, tourists aren't traveling and businesses are hurting in Manhattan. Around lunchtime on a bright sunny Tuesday the week before Christmas, there was plenty of space to spread out and take selfies in front of the Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree.

title: College Football's Playoff: Alabama, Clemson, Ohio State, Notre Dame...and No Surprises
summary: After a chaotic season on the brink, the final four is very familiar. Because it is college football, and college football is a uniquely paradoxical enterprise, it was bound to turn out like this: The most bonkers season in memory, rife with postponements, cancellations, and hastily assembled games-plus a constant worry the whole deal was hanging by an epidemiological string-would conclude with a four-team playoff that is so clubby and familiar, you could have accurately outlined at least three-quarters of it on a hotel napkin a half decade ago.

title: Pope Francis Warns Against Division in Response to Church Scandals
summary: Pontiff says bad news shouldn't discourage church after a year dogged by crises. ROME-Pope Francis urged hope and warned against polarization in response to crisis in the Catholic Church, at the end of a year marked by scandals over financial dealings and sex abuse that besmirched the reputations of the last three popes and other prominent clerics.

title: The Single Fashion Item That Got Me Through 2020
summary: Top stylists, who work with Justin Bieber, A$AP Rocky, Charlize Theron and Harry Styles between them, share the secret items that saved their sanity this year. This year will go down in the history books for many reasons from the tragic to the absurd-but it will also be remembered as the year it became a challenge just to get dressed. With that in mind, WSJ. turned to the most influential architects behind the style of today's biggest stars, including Justin Bieber's longtime stylist Karla Welch, Charlize Theron's fashionable right-hand Leslie Fremar and A$AP Rocky's collaborator Matt Henson. We asked them: What got you through? Turns out it was a tough slog even for the professionals, but, with the help of pieces including chic sweats and Schitt's Creek-inspired brooches, they made it.

title: German Yom Kippur Shooter Sentenced to Life
summary: German court hands highest available sentence to man who killed two in attack on synagogue in 2019. BERLIN-A German court Monday handed a life sentence to the man who killed two and attempted to kill dozens of others in an attack on a synagogue during Yom Kippur last year, one in a string of far-right, anti-Semitic and racist plots that have surfaced in Germany in recent years.

title: Covid-19 Pandemic Relief Package Reaches Final Agreement in Congress
summary: Package expected to include $600 checks for many Americans and $300 a week in extra jobless aid. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers reached a final agreement on the roughly $900 billion coronavirus relief package, moving Congress closer to approval of a fresh infusion of aid to households, small businesses and schools after months of gridlock.

title: Why Many Bosses Won't Require Workers to Get the Covid-19 Vaccine
summary: Companies plan to encourage, incentivize vaccination; 'Here is the carrot, and here is the stick'. Some of America's largest businesses say they will encourage-but not mandate-employees to get Covid-19 vaccines, using a mix of incentives and consequences to ensure as many workers as possible are inoculated.

title: U.S. Evidence Against Mexican Ex-Defense Minister Raises Conviction Doubts
summary: The case that Gen. Salvador Cienfuegos took bribes from drug cartels is largely circumstantial, people in both countries say, clouding chances of a conviction in Mexico. Explosive U.S. drug-trafficking allegations against Mexico's former defense minister rely largely on circumstantial evidence, diminishing the chances that the Mexican government could bring a case against him to trial or could convict him in a Mexican court if it did, according to people in both countries familiar with the case.

title: Biden Adds New Members to His White House Economic Team
summary: President-elect hires David Kamin, a former Obama administration budget official, and Bharat Ramamurti, a longtime aide to Sen. Elizabeth Warren. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden is rounding out his economic team, adding a longtime aide to Sen. Elizabeth Warren and a former Obama administration budget official to his National Economic Council.

title: George Clooney Cuts His Own Hair. Should You?
summary: With many barber shops open again, some men have raced back to professional trimmers, while others plan to keep shearing their own strands. We debate each approach's merits.. For the recurring series, That's Debatable, we take on a contentious issue of the day and present two spirited arguments-one in favor and other emphatically opposed. Previous installments from the series are here.

title: Tesla, Zoom, Nike: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: U.S. stock futures tumbled as a new coronavirus strain triggered travel curbs and hit shares of American Airlines, Delta and Boeing. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Monday.Futures tied to the S&P 500 dropped 1.6%, as a fast-spreading strain of coronavirus emerging from England prompted fresh travel restrictions, dealing another blow to prospects for the global economic recovery. Futures linked to the technology heavy Nasdaq-100 index fell 1.1%.

title: Adam Brody on Surfing His "Brains Out" With Leighton Meester
summary: "Other new hobbies? Honestly, we're just beach bums.". In our series My Monday Morning, self-motivated people tell WSJ. how they start off the week.

title: The Case of the NBA's Most Stolen Play
summary: How does an idea travel from a small college in Kentucky to Celtics coach Brad Stevens, Warriors coach Steve Kerr and the highest levels of basketball?. At the biggest moment of an NBA Finals game with a championship at stake, Golden State Warriors coach Steve Kerr called a play for the greatest shooter in basketball history.

title: Ugly Christmas Sweaters: Holiday Fun or Commercialized Insanity?
summary: The spread of tacky holiday sweaters emblazoned with movie gags, corporation logos and dirty slogans has turned this once-quaint phenomenon into an overwhelming marketplace. LIKE OH SO many things related to the holidays, the ugly Christmas sweater craze was once a far quainter phenomenon. Back in the 2000s, when people first threw parties themed around tacky yuletide knits, guests mostly relied on luck to scrounge up a suitably hideous example. Maybe, digging through your attic, you found your mother's 1980s Santa sweater. Perhaps, at Goodwill, you chanced upon a vintage red-and-green sweater repulsively adorned with jingle bells.

title: Under Covid's Pall, CIOs Looked to Employees' Emotional Health in 2020
summary: 'The new approach for CIOs must be technology plus empathy,' said Carol Juel, CIO of Synchrony Financial. This year, many chief information officers gave priority to the mental health and well-being of their employees more than ever before, offering access to psychological resources and sharing personal experiences to strengthen bonds.

title: Less Meeting, More Meditation
summary: Finding the right (remote) work-life balance takes work, CIOs find. Several IT executives discussed ways that they are encouraging their teams to pursue the right work-life balance during the pandemic.

title: Booking Investors Should Have More Reservations
summary: Online travel agent's shares have risen even though its business has crashed this year and a years-long recovery is in store. Stock-market froth has spilled over even into decades-old technology mainstays. Online travel agent Booking Holdings has erased all of its losses this year in the stock market and has kept rising, even as its actual business remains deeply challenged.

title: Covid-19 Means Millions of Americans Face the Holidays With Loss
summary: Americans are grieving and trying to pick up the pieces; 'Holidays? What are those?'. Round Rock, Texas, resident Mandy Troia recently put a note on her Facebook page, telling friends to get in touch if they needed a little assistance meeting expenses this holiday season.

title: Superpedestrian Gets $60 Million Funding Boost
summary: Electric-scooter firm eyes dozens of new markets as Citigroup, others invest. An electric scooter company vying for a place in New York City's ride-share pilot program has secured $60 million in funding from investors, including the sponsor of the city's popular bike-share program.

title: Shell Signals Another Poor Quarter for Oil Majors
summary: Energy giant warns of third-consecutive quarterly loss for its oil-and-gas production business, and a further write-down. Royal Dutch Shell PLC said it would write down the value of its assets by up to $4.5 billion and warned of another set of poor earnings for the fourth quarter, showing how the oil-and-gas industry continues to struggle amid the fallout of the pandemic.

title: Project44 Gains $100 Million in New Backing
summary: Latest funding round will support expansion of the company's visibility platform, boosting its services and geographic reach on the way to possible public offering. Logistics technology provider project44 raised $100 million in a Series D funding round that will help to expand the reach of its supply-chain visibility software and build its business as it weighs a potential public stock offering over the long term.

title: Covid Is Pushing Women Out of Work. Just Look at Italy.
summary: Italy's gender employment gap is now the widest in Europe. ROME-Margherita Marino was a successful family lawyer in Naples, running a small but thriving practice, until the pandemic struck. Now she spends nearly all her time taking care of her two children, who have mostly been at home since March due to prolonged school closures.

title: The Flood Gates Still Aren't Open for Banks-Yet
summary: The Federal Reserve is letting banks pay out more to shareholders, but likely not enough to sop up big excess capital buffers that drag on returns. The Federal Reserve has finally started to lift the lockdown on bank buybacks, but not by so much that investors should be making big new holiday plans.

title: SolarWinds Hack Targeted Tech Firms, University
summary: A Wall Street Journal analysis identified at least 24 organizations that installed software laced with malicious code by Russian hackers. The suspected Russian hackers behind breaches at U.S. government agencies also gained access to major U.S. technology and accounting companies, at least one hospital and a university, a Wall Street Journal analysis of internet records found.

title: The Jets Won-and May Have Lost Trevor Lawrence
summary: Finishing the season winless, to secure the No. 1 pick in the draft, was the best move for the Jets' future. They beat the Los Angeles Rams instead..

title: Countries Ban Travel From U.K. in Race to Block New Covid-19 Strain
summary: Germany, France, Italy, Canada, Israel, the Netherlands and Belgium on Sunday announced bans on passenger air travel from the U.K.. Countries across Europe and beyond barred travelers from Britain on Sunday in an effort to keep out a highly infectious new strain of the coronavirus that is spreading rapidly in England.

title: Fracking: From Breaking Shale to Breaking Even
summary: Understanding the mechanics and economics of fracking can help investors understand the dizzyingly cyclical nature of energy markets. Everyone seems to have an opinion about fracking. The revolutionary and controversial oil-and-gas exploration technique has raised the ire of oil sheikhs, investors and environmentalists while minting billionaires and wiping out tens of billions of dollars fronted by many of their lenders and investors.

title: Dutch Program Aims to Deter Young Hackers
summary: Police initiative informs young people about hacking laws and alternative ways to use their skills. Floor Jansen, a Dutch police officer who worked on drug smuggling and organized crime until a few years ago, is on a mission to reform teenage hackers.

title: Companies' Internal Auditors Test Earlier for Risks
summary: The departments tasked with assessing corporate risks are dealing with a wider range of them. Internal auditors are testing their companies' controls over key processes and procedures earlier than normal and reevaluating risks as they deal with a wider range of issues that could imperil the business during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: MoneyGram Backs Stronger Due-Diligence Rule
summary: The money-transfer company supports a proposal to broaden the scope of transactions for which institutions need to collect and pass along information. A proposal by regulators that would require financial institutions to collect and pass along sender and receiver details on more transactions has raised concerns at many firms about compliance costs. But one of the largest money-transfer companies is putting its weight behind the effort.

title: Luxury Brands Will Go Shopping Again
summary: Next year, powerful labels will face their old dilemma of what to do with excess cash. This year, luxury companies were more likely to try to back out of deals than to sign new ones. That could soon change as cash piles up on the larger players' balance sheets, while independent brands come under pressure to invest.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: New Yorkers Spent 2020 Reading About Race
summary: 'The Vanishing Half,' 'White Fragility' top New York Public Library's annual list of most borrowed books. When it came to reading material this past year, New Yorkers turned to books that helped them make sense of our increasingly challenging world, particularly in terms of race relations and social justice.

title: Thoma Bravo to Buy RealPage for $9.6 Billion
summary: Private-equity firm reaches deal with provider of technology platform used by owners and managers of rental properties. Private-equity firm Thoma Bravo LP has struck a deal to buy property-management-software provider RealPage Inc. for $9.6 billion, in one of the largest recent leveraged buyouts.

title: Cold Cuts (Monday Crossword, December 21)
